answers.answer: You need to be under the care of an ophthalmologist. Depending on size and location most branch retinal vein occlusions do not require treatment. It is imporant to rule out cardiovascular disease causing this so you need good physical exam by internist or family doctor with blood work, ekg.If you smoke or are overweight these need to be treated. High cholesteral and high blood pressure are especially important to treat if present.JCH MD

Branch retinal vein occlusion BRVO should not be caused by thyroid problems. As I mentioned the main risks are smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesteral, diabetes, blood that is abnornally thick and several other rare causes. BRVO is usually less serious than central retinal vein occlusion CRVO. If the BRVO is remove from the macula the prognosis is excellent and often no treatment is necessary other than treat any underlying medical conditions that might cause the condition. Sometimes low dose aspririn is prescribed. For completeness sake I should mention that undiagnosed or poorly controled glaucoma can cause BRVO. Your ophthalmologist would have excluded this by your examination.  In some instances of the macula is involved and vision affected and the problem not resolving laser therapy is used to try and 'dry up" the retinal.JCH MD

I am 34 Years old Male, i have diabetes but well controlled, BP 115/70, eye pressure is 16 & 15 all blood works came in negative, I was diagnosed with BRVO on my left eye, doctor recommended 3X Lucentis injections over 3 months, i am scheduled for my first injection this coming Saturday. my vision in both eyes is 20/20 but i cant see very well in my left eye due to the "gray spots" i wanted to check if anyone had the same experience and what was the outcome of the injections.doctor was very optimistic and said that my chances based on his experience is to regain 80% - 95% of my vision in the left eye.please share with me your experience.

multiple injections will likely be needed. For large amounts of swelling (edema) that fail to resolve such injections are treatment of choice.  control all your risk factors to avoid more BRVO   i.e. keep blood pressure, A1C, cholesterol/triglycerides in good range, stay slim, don't smoke, eat good diet, exercise.JCH MD
